title: 114_hr4740
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cybercrime Enforcement Training Assistance Act of 2016" and includes provisions for local law enforcement grants. The "Cybercrime Enforcement Training Assistance Act of 2016" authorizes grants for states and local governments to prevent, enforce, and prosecute cybercrimes against individuals. To apply for a grant, the chief executive officer must submit an application to the Attorney General within 90 days of funds being appropriated, certifying that federal funds will not replace state or local funds. The application for grants under the "Cybercrime Enforcement Training Assistance Act of 2016" must include assurances that the funds will not replace state or local funds, were reviewed by the governing body, made public, and allowed for public comments before submission to the Attorney General. The application for grants under the "Cybercrime Enforcement Training Assistance Act of 2016" must include assurances that public comments were allowed, data will be maintained and reported as required by the Attorney General, and a certification signed by the chief executive officer of the applicant. The application for grants must include assurances that programs meet requirements, information is correct, coordination with agencies has been done, and compliance with laws will be ensured. Additionally, a certification of criminal laws against cybercrimes must be in effect. The grant application must include assurances that programs meet requirements and comply with laws, including certification of criminal laws against cybercrimes. Grant funds must be used primarily for investigations and forensic analysis of evidence in cybercrimes against individuals. Training for law enforcement personnel on identifying and assisting victims of cybercrimes against individuals is also required. Training for law enforcement personnel, prosecutors, judges, and judicial personnel to identify, investigate, prosecute, and enforce laws against cybercrimes targeting individuals, including the use of technology and overtime payment for training. Training for law enforcement personnel, prosecutors, judges, and judicial personnel to identify, investigate, prosecute, and enforce laws against cybercrimes targeting individuals, including the use of technology and resources to assist victims. Training for State or local emergency dispatch personnel to identify and protect victims of cybercrimes against individuals. Assistance provided includes training law enforcement personnel to utilize resources and technology for cybercrime victim assistance, payment of overtime for training, aiding in enforcing laws against cybercrimes, and educating the public to prevent such crimes. Assistance provided includes aiding law enforcement in investigating cybercrimes against individuals, supporting task forces for forensic analyses and prosecutions, helping acquire necessary equipment for investigations, and promoting efforts to combat cybercrimes. Assistance includes aiding law enforcement in investigating cybercrimes against individuals, supporting task forces for forensic analyses and prosecutions, and helping with interstate extradition requests for cybercrime violations. Annual reports are required for grants received by State or local governments. The chief executive of a State or local government must submit an annual report to the Attorney General detailing activities carried out with any received grants, evaluating results, and providing requested information. The Attorney General must then submit a compilation of this information to Congress every even-numbered fiscal year. Authorization of appropriations is also included. In general, $20,000,000 is authorized annually for fiscal years 2017 through 2021 for cybercrime prevention. Not more than 5 percent of the funds can be used for evaluation, monitoring, technical assistance, salaries, and administrative expenses. Definitions include cybercrimes against individuals involving personal harm using a computer. The term "computer" includes a computer network and an interactive electronic device. It does not include the use of a computer to cause harm to a commercial entity, government agency, or any non-natural persons. SEC. 3. NATIONAL RESOURCE CENTER GRANT. The Attorney General awards grants for a National Resource Center on Cybercrimes Against Individuals to provide training and assistance to prevent and prosecute cybercrimes. Eligible entities must submit an application within 90 days of funds being appropriated for the fiscal year, including a commitment to maintain and report data. The applicant must maintain and report data as required by the Attorney General for a grant. A certification must be submitted confirming program compliance and accuracy of information. The grant funds are to be used for a National Resource Center on Cybercrimes Against Individuals, providing technical assistance. The curr_chunk discusses the responsibilities of the National Resource Center on Cybercrimes Against Individuals, which include offering technical assistance and training, maintaining a resource library, and conducting research related to cybercrimes against individuals. The National Resource Center on Cybercrimes Against Individuals is responsible for providing technical assistance, training, maintaining a resource library, and conducting research on the causes and effects of cybercrimes against individuals. Grants awarded under this section are for a duration of 5 years and can be renewed for additional 5-year periods if funds are used appropriately. The eligible entity awarded a grant under this section may make subgrants to other nonprofit private organizations with relevant expertise to establish and maintain the National Resource Center on Cybercrimes Against Individuals. The entity must submit an annual report to the Attorney General summarizing activities and evaluating results of the grant program. The Attorney General must submit a report to Congress every even-numbered fiscal year containing information from the previous report. $4,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2017 through 2021. Definitions for "cybercrimes against individuals" and "eligible entity" are provided in this section. An eligible entity is a nonprofit organization focusing on cybercrimes against individuals, with experience in this area and a diverse advisory board.
